message: This morning @POTUS urged Democrats to unite to fight for the healthcare of Americans.  #ACAWorks Thanks to the #ACA, 203,000 people in Missouri have gained health coverage.

As the Senate begins to hold confirmation hearings this week, it is important that all cabinet nominees be fully vetted to protect the American people.

Today is the second day of Senator Sessions nomination hearing. We need an Attorney General  that will defend and enforce our laws and protect civil rights. Someone who is unequivocally committed to the principles of racial, ethnic, gender, religious, and sexual orientation equality. Sen. Sessions’ voting record and public comments raise concerns about his ability to make that commitment.

Access to health care is not the same as providing affordable insurance coverage. Rep. Tom Price, President-elect Trump’s nominee for Secretary of HHS, needs to commit to providing affordable insurance to all Americans and to protect those with pre-existing conditions. Yesterday the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office reported that repealing the Affordable Care Act would lead to 18 million people losing coverage in the first year.

Today, the House of Representatives will vote on H.R. 7. This dangerous bill would take away private health insurance coverage from millions of women and undermine a woman’s ability to make personal decisions about her own health. This action comes just days after millions of women marched nationwide to protect their rights and over 10,000 Kansas Citians gathered in support. The bill  would take away the tax credits women are entitled to in order to help buy insurance and would make the Hyde Amendment and other federal abortion bans permanent. This legislation does not allow any exceptions for women to get the coverage they need when their health is in danger, even in circumstances where a woman needs an abortion to prevent severe, permanent damage to her health  The  Affordable Care Act set out rules to ensure federal financial assistance is not used to pay for abortion services, except in the case  of rape, incest and life endangerment. Thanks to the ACA providing better access to birth control and family planning services, the U.S. abortion rate is at its lowest level on record. The abortion rate dropped 14 percent between 2011 and 2014.  H.R. 7 would take away a women’s ability to make an extremely personal medical decision. I plan to  vote against this harmful piece of legislation and stand with the thousands of my constituents who marched to have their voices heard this weekend. #WeWontGoBack

Last night, Senator Warren was silenced on the Senate floor during debate on Senator Session's nomination as Attorney General when she attempted to read this letter, written by Coretta Scott King in 1986 opposing the appointment of Senator Jeff Sessions as a federal judge nominee. If you haven’t read the letter written by the late, Mrs. King, you should. Now, Senator Sessions stands before us again, this time as a nominee for Attorney General. How are we to examine our nominees if we can’t examine their history? I’m proud of @SenWarren for standing up. #ShePersisted #LetLizSpeak. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/01/10/read-the-letter-coretta-scott-king-wrote-opposing-sessionss-1986-federal-nomination/?hpid=hp_rhp-top-table-main_letter-7a%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.889f13839443

In November of 2016, I joined Congresswoman Robin Kelly and other members of the Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) in writing a letter to Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg. The letter addressed reports of advertisers on Facebook, using a customization feature called “Ethnic Affinities” which excluded racial and ethnic groups when placing online housing advertisements. Today, I’m pleased to hear the news that Facebook has committed to improving its website by prohibiting discrimination in online advertisement and promoting diversity. Thank you, Facebook, for working with us and for listening. #CBCTECH2020

This latest proposal by the Republicans guts the Affordable Care Act and ends access to health care as we know it. This isn’t replacement, this is an elimination - snatching healthcare away from millions of Americans. This plan would cut Medicaid and force older Americans to pay more out of pocket. The only people who will benefit from this plan are the big insurance companies and the wealthy with extreme tax breaks. The purpose of the ACA was to ensure that all Americans regardless of income, age or health status would be able to receive health care. This plan defeats that purpose, making our country sicker.
Had to see the damage myself here in Oak Grove, MO. This community is resilient.

In a markup in the Financial Services Committee last week, I spoke in favor of New York Congressman Gregory Meeks’ amendment that highlighted the importance of the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program. The CDBG program is important for development efforts in both urban and rural communities. The more we fail to see the symbiotic relationship between urban and rural areas, the more damage we will do to this country.

Under #Trumpcare, health insurance premiums will significantly increase for older and low-income consumers, leaving many with no option for affordable coverage. A 64-year old making 175% of the federal poverty level (or $26,500 a year) will see his or her yearly premium increase nearly $13,000. That means they would have to spend almost half their income on health care alone. According to the @CBO, 24 million Americans would lose health coverage by 2026 under this plan.

#CleanerCars drive economic growth while saving us money at the pump. We can’t afford to reverse this progress. President Trump’s decision to reverse fuel efficiency and clean car standards is a hidden tax on families – literally making everything they do more expensive and more dangerous to their health. Tailpipe pollution causes 53k early deaths EACH YEAR. We can’t afford to roll back #CleanerCars standards.

Today is #EqualPayDay, the day that women's wages finally catch up to what men were paid in the previous year.  Equal Pay Day is a day to focus on the economic inequality still facing women throughout our nation and to look at ways in which we can overcome this serious and persistent problem.  Currently, women are paid 80 cents for every dollar that men make and in Missouri it is worse, with women making only 78 cents to that dollar.  Women of color have the highest hill to climb, with African-American women earning just 63 cents for every dollar and Latinas earning just 54 cents.  We must do more to confront this issue!  https://nwlc.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/FAQ-About-the-Wage-Gap-2016-5.pdf

Social Security is a bedrock program that has benefited countless Americans since its inception in 1935.  It is not an entitlement program; it is an insurance program that you've paid into with every paycheck.  That is why I'm joining Congressman John Larson on the Social Security 2100 Act.  I'm looking to strengthen Social Security for generations to come and this legislation will go a long way in making that happen.

Tomorrow is officially #EarthDay, a day to appreciate the world we all share and to promote the well-being of our planet.  Scientists overwhelmingly agree that Climate Change is a significant problem as we move forward and must be addressed immediately.  If we continue down the path the current administration is leading, Climate Change will have a negative impact on our weather, health, and economy.  I encourage you to get out tomorrow and find Earth Day events happening near you.  We only have one planet, we must do all we can to protect it!

Yesterday, House Republicans showed their true colors when they voted to strip healthcare away from millions of Americans.  The ill-conceived and poorly executed TrumpCare bill will eliminate healthcare from more than 20 million people, cause out-of-pocket costs to rise, force those with pre-existing conditions to pay more for less coverage--the list of negative consequences goes on and on. While yesterday was a very sad day for our country, the fight is not over. Americans deserve access to affordable healthcare and I will do everything within my power to make sure they keep it.   https://goo.gl/0I8qg0

Last night Donald J. Trump fired the man investigating his own campaign's ties to Russia. Regardless of which side of the aisle you are on, this is a deeply troubling decision. The decision Donald Trump made and the reasons behind it do not pass the smell test for even a second. Russia's intention last November was to destabilize our democracy, something that seems to be working better than they could have ever expected. Last night, Vladimir Putin continued to see the fruits of his labor. It is time for both parties to come together for the sake of our democracy and call for an independent investigation into Trump's ties to Russia.  https://goo.gl/1Ek9F9

Student loan debt is one of the greater challenges our country faces as we move forward. At 1:00 p.m. CST on May 30, I will be holding a Facebook Live event focused on this important issue. I will discuss some of the problems current students are facing, while also presenting some ideas I think would be beneficial for future students aspiring to obtain a college education without crippling their future finances. I will also be taking questions from constituents live, or you can send your questions to CleaverTownHall@mail.house.gov beforehand.  I look forward to examining this critical issue and can't wait to speak with all of you next week!

The proposal would cut $1.4 trillion from Medicaid, target Social Security benefits, and make it harder for struggling families to put food on the table and a roof over their head--all to help pay for massive tax cuts for the wealthy. This budget does not represent our American values and I will fight it every step of the way.  https://goo.gl/FKP8aR

Today President Trump made the decision to pull the United States out of the Paris Climate Accord, a decision history will look back on with disappointment and regret. Climate Change is an existential threat, not only to the United States, but the planet as a whole. It is not only an environmental concern, but an economic, defense, national security, and immigration issue as well. Pulling out of the Paris Accord leaves the potential for serious backlash, and increases the likelihood that our nation will be drawn into foreign conflicts over scarce resources and refugees. While the rest of the world moves towards a clean energy economy, the United States will now be put at an economic disadvantage, trying to play catch-up while the rest of the world innovates and invests in clean energy. With virtual consensus among scientists, the backing of close to 200 nations, and the support of major economic/business leaders, President Trump's decision to pull out of this international agreement--in order to keep an empty promise to Big Oil and Big Coal--is absolutely indefensible. While President Trump has taken the United States a step back as a global leader, I will continue to fight for a safer, cleaner and more sustainable environmental agenda. https://goo.gl/TD5waQ

Yesterday James Comey, the former FBI Director, testified before the Senate Intelligence committee. I appreciate his willingness to come forward and speak, under oath, on his interactions with President Trump. Here is my statement regarding his testimony: https://goo.gl/QCc8e0

Today marks the one year anniversary of the Pulse Nightclub Massacre, in which 49 innocent people were senselessly killed and more than 50 others injured--the deadliest single gunman mass shooting in US history. My heart goes out to every victim and to their friends and family, I can only imagine the grief they feel. And while they may be gone, the overwhelming support being shown is an indication that those killed will never be forgotten. We owe it to each and every victim to reject the evil and hatred at the root of this terrible tragedy and to show the world that we are a society based on love and acceptance. Love will always trump hate, and today we show that by standing with the victims, their families, Orlando, and the LGBT community.

I am excited to announce over $38 million in federal funding has been provided in the U.S. Army Corps' Fiscal Year 2017 work plan to complete the Blue River Basin/Dodson Levee and the Turkey Creek Basin Projects in the Kansas City area. Since Congress passed the Water Resources Development Act last year, I have been fighting to provide funding for these projects, and I am happy to say that Kansas City will now reap the rewards. In total, over $38 million will be used to complete both of these flood-control projects, protecting the more than 1,500 people and over $380 million in property investment in the Dodson Industrial Area and providing over $5 million in annual benefits to the area surrounding Turkey Creek. The completion of these projects has been a long time coming and I am happy I was able to contribute on behalf of my constituents in the 5th Congressional District. https://goo.gl/jqtH6y

Today the Senate released it's devastating #TrumpCare bill. Written by 12 men in a back room, one week before the vote, with no hearing or public input. But I don't want to talk about the lack of transparency or undemocratic process this bill has gone through in the Senate, I want to talk about the harmful impact it will have on America's most vulnerable citizens. This bill, as written, will hurt seniors, women, veterans, working families, rural communities, and people with pre-existing conditions. It defunds Planned Parenthood, steals from Medicare, and guts Medicaid. It does away with essential health benefits, taking us back to the days where being a woman was considered a pre-existing condition. The only people it won't hurt are healthy Americans and wealthy Americans. That's because this is not a health bill at all. It is a tax bill meant to slash taxes for the wealthiest in our nation, all at the expense of our most disabled and disadvantaged. Please share if you agree that this bill should not pass the Senate. Please know that I will continue to fight for healthcare for ALL Americans and together we can stop this monstrous bill from becoming law.

Today marks the 228th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille and a turning point in the French Revolution. In recognition of the centennial of America's entrance into WWI and in a show of solidarity from Emmanuel Macron, the US Army 1st Infantry Division--the first US unit to enter France in 1917-- was invited to lead the #BastilleDay parade amongst the French armed forces. We were lucky enough to host the 1st Infantry Division in Kansas City earlier this year for the WWI Centennial Commemoration and I'm pleased to see them continue to get the recognition they deserve. Being a major WWI advocate, I want to personally thank President Macron for honoring the efforts of the American armed forces during the Great War. Happy #BastilleDay to France and all French-Americans. Enjoy your day! World War One Centennial Commission Patrouille de France National World War I Museum and Memorial

I want to thank MCC-Penn Valley for allowing me to host my town hall at their Education Center, Dia Wall for doing such a tremendous job moderating, and everyone who came to the town hall last night. I'd also like to give a special thank you to everyone who was willing to tell their student loan story so that we can better understand this pivotal issue. We were able to have an insightful and in-depth discussion on what is working within the federal student loan system and, more importantly, what needs to be fixed. My staff and I will be taking all of your experiences, observations, and thoughts on the current system and continue to work on legislation that will ease the heavy burden that student loans have put on our students. Thanks again for voicing your opinions and please continue to be ACTIVE in raising awareness on this crucial issue. The only way to truly address the student loan crisis is if the people demand change, so continue to make your voices heard!

Over the past 7 months, in spite of everything to the contrary, I believed that Mr. Trump would adorn the coat of president honorably. When he failed to condemn the white supremacists parading as patriots in Charlottesville, I accepted the reality that what I have been waiting on is something that just won't happen. I am not going to hate President Trump. I will not place him in the category of the unforgiven. In fact, on this very night, I will pray for him as the Bible requires. However, I must now admit that I just don't like Donald Trump!

Lordy, lordy. I now believe that the President's natural inclination is to make matters worse. He ran a White House that had become a mess, but he has magnificently and proudly turned it into a Mess Hall. Equating the Klan and the Nazis with civil rights organizations and those whose very existence is based on destroying huge segments of the American population is a maze from which escape might prove nigh impossible. Anyone who justifies this behavior needs to fill out an application to work in the West Wing.

Yesterday, a Democratic Missouri state senator, Maria Chappelle-Nadal, wrote and posted the following: "I hope Trump is assassinated." As a lifelong Democrat, I'm horrified at such an ignorant and dangerous statement. However, I was gratified to see that Democratic state representative Gail McCann-Beatty possessed the courage and character to call for senator Chapelle-Nadal to resign immediately. Lately, our nation has seen far too many elected officials, particularly on the national level, experience a weak-kneed collapse of character when courage was required to go beyond party affiliation to address President Donald Trump's verbal villainy in response to hate groups. Senator Chappelle-Nadal should resign. Hoping that someone kill anyone is reckless and borders on gangsterism. Rep McCann-Beatty, the character you have displayed, in this politically polarized moment, reflects the height of your ideals and the depths of your judgement. Few would criticize a political colleague whom you see every day.

Former Mayors and long-time friends, Emanuel Cleaver, II and Richard Berkley after lunch. Congressman Cleaver, a Democrat and Mayor Berkley, a former state chair of the Republican party. We both miss the good ole’ days when hating members of the other party was not a requirement.
Unfortunately, President Trump is expected to end #DACA. Here is my statement:  https://goo.gl/Wh7wCz

This morning, in a genuine show of character--or lack thereof--President Trump officially rescinded the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, known as #DACA, program. Day after day, this president shows his total disconnect from authentic American values, most notably, morality and empathy. The decision to remove 800,000 CHILDREN from the United States, the only home they have ever known, is the cruelest and most heartless action that this president has made--a truly sad display of American leadership.  To all the #DREAMers: This is not the sincere attitude of America. This is the heart of a man and an administration pandering to a small segment of their party, a strictly political decision. The vast majority of Americans empathize with your situation and understand the extensive contributions that DREAMers provide our nation. You are our neighbors, our friends, our brother and sisters. You are Americans. We respect you, we stand with you, and we will continue to fight for you until we can fight no more.  Esta no es la posición sincera de los Estados Unidos. Esta decisión muestra el corazón de un hombre y una administración queriendo complacer a un segmento pequeño de su partido. Esta fue una decisión política.  La mayoría de los Estadounidenses simpatizan con su situación y entendemos las grandes contribuciones que los Dreamers aportan a nuestra nación. Ustedes son nuestros vecinos, amigos, hermanos y hermanas. Ustedes son Americanos. Los respetamos, estamos con ustedes y seguiremos luchando por ustedes hasta que ya no podamos luchar más.

As we come to the end of September and National Suicide Prevention Month, I'd like to bring more attention to this devastating problem. Suicide takes the lives of more than 44,000 Americans every year, leaving family and friends to deal with unthinkable grief & the agonizing question of "why?" Suicide is the second leading cause of death for individuals aged 15-34 and 3rd leading cause of death for kids aged 10-14, according to the CDC. It is the tenth leading cause of death overall in the United States with almost twice as many people dying by suicide than from homicide. This is truly an epidemic. Young Americans are dying unnecessarily every day and I feel an honest obligation to do something about it. For these reasons, I have sponsored a bill, H.R. 3552, the "Cady Housh and Jason Flatt Teen Suicide Prevention Act," that will help address this heartbreaking issue. I want to give a special thank you to The Jason Foundation, Inc. -Youth Suicide Prevention and Awareness, an organization that has worked tirelessly to advance awareness of youth suicide and work with state legislatures to give schools the help they need in dealing with this growing dilemma. Now it's time to work on this at the national level, and I look forward to working with other Members until every school has the proper resources to deal with this pervasive problem.  https://goo.gl/4VUsJB

While Betsy DeVos and President Trump advance an agenda that favors debt collectors over students, I will continue to fight for hardworking Americans. I, along with Rep. Luke Messer, have introduced H.R. 4119, The Student Loan Disclosure Modernization Act, a bipartisan bill that will simplify the Department of Education's "Plain Language Disclosure Form." Currently, 44 million Americans owe more than $1.3 trillion in student loan debt, many of whom don't fully understand the loan obligations. My bill would help to simplify what is presently a confusing standardized form so that students have a more complete understanding of the loan options available to them and how the loans will affect them in the future. It is my hope that every American who wants to improve their circumstances through higher education has the opportunity to do so without unnecessary financial burdens, and that begins with clearly and simply education these students before they take out a loan. For more information on the legislation, you can find it here: https://goo.gl/bgAFco

Earlier this year, Congressman Luis V. Gutierrez and I sent a letter to two of the biggest private prison companies in the United States, requesting they support criminal justice reform efforts. Way too little is done to educate students about their student loans. That's why Rep. Luke Messer and I introduced H.R. 4119--The Student Loan Disclosure Modernization Act--to simplify the "Plain Language Disclosure Form," which is anything but "plain." Look, Americans already owe $1.3 trillion in outstanding student loan debt, it is essential that student borrowers receive a complete understanding of the loans they are taking out. With the passage of H.R. 4119, that is exactly what will happen. https://goo.gl/MniQn5

Yesterday, I voted against the continuing resolution (CR), which funds the government through January 19.  Instead of spending so much time on tax breaks for the wealthy and corporations, our first priority should have been fully funding the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) and Community Health Centers without taking funding away from other programs that help families and children with vaccinations, substance abuse and youth suicide prevention. CHIP is widely used in Missouri and covers the healthcare of 13,000 children in my district and 9 million children nationwide.  This CR should have also protected our Dreamers. Passing the DREAM Act is of major importance to help those children and families facing deportation from the only home they've ever known.    It is my hope that when Congress reconvenes in 2018 we can come together and find some bipartisan solutions to these pressing issues.

President Donald Trump signed executive orders on immigration. These changes to immigration will affect thousands of families here in the Kansas City area and throughout the 5th district.  Congressman Emanuel Cleaver, II will hold a Town Hall Meeting to address these immediate changes to our country's immigration policies. Congressman Cleaver will provide a panel of experts in the field to listen to concerns and answer questions families may have regarding the potential elimination of the DACA program and any changes to the refugee visa program. Panelist information forthcoming.

How do student loans affect you? Come share your student loan story with Congressman Cleaver and engage in a back-and-forth discussion on the federal student loan crisis. Federal student loans are a $1.4 trillion problem that hinders far too many Kansas Citians. Congressman Cleaver wants to hear the good, the bad, and the ugly to look for ways in which we can strengthen the federal student loan system to ease the burden of loans on students.
